In a 39-year-old male with a subacute onset (3 weeks) of a focal brainstem syndrome, the differential is broad. Inflammatory/demyelinating causes (e.g., MS, Neurosarcoidosis) and space-occupying lesions (Glioma, Metastasis) are top priorities given the timeline and age. Vascular causes (stroke/vascular malformation) are possible if the onset was acute and stable, though the subacute nature favours non-vascular aetiologies. Infectious causes (e.g., Listeria, TB, HIV-related) must be excluded.
